parameters.source_text:
Case 7-4
Refusing to Learn about Cancer
Wesley Crossman was a 43-year-old real estate broker who had just been
hospitalized for persistent pain in the bone of his right hip. At first he
thought he must have pulled a muscle, but the pain gradually became
more severe. About six months ago, after he had endured the pain for
almost a month, he went to his family physician, who made a tentative di-
agnosis of arthritis. After several months of treatment with indomethacin,
an antiarthritic drug, during which time the pain became unbearable, re-
ferral was made to an orthopedic specialist for further tests.
Mr. Crossman was the proprietor of a small agency in a suburb of
Phoenix, Arizona, in the path of urban growth. Although only marginally
successful, he earned enough to support his wife and three children, who
were now 18, 14, and 12. The rapid development of the area gave him new
hope for some promising real estate speculation. After overcoming his
wife's concerns about the financial risks, he invested $20,000 from their
savings account in a development project. It would take a few years to pay
off, but he was tired of making fortunes on land for everyone else while he
and his family made so little.
Mr. Crossman felt tense when he went to the appointment with Dr. Marvin
Greenblatt, the orthopedic specialist. He had not said anything explicit to
his wife, but they were both thinking about the neighbor who had succumbed
to bone cancer. During the examination, Mr. Crossman remarked that he
was a busy man and mentioned his real estate deal to Dr. Greenblatt when
he was asked what he did for a living. Then Mr. Crossman got down to
business and stated, “Doctor, you do what you have to do to get rid of this
pain,” he said. “Put me in the hospital if you have to, but don't trouble me
with all the details. Do what you think is best. Even if it’s awful, I'd just as
soon not know.” Both Mr. Crossman and Dr. Greenblatt knew that “cancer”
was the word he would not or could not say.
Dr. Greenblatt had seen patients like Mr. Crossman before. Some pa-
tients give signals, just as clear as can be, that a diagnosis of a terminal
illness would be more than they could handle psychologically. Dr. Greenblatt
asked himself, however, “Does he have a right not to know the truth?”

data.vignette: A 43-year-old man is admitted for severe right hip pain and difficulty walking. Imaging shows a destructive bone lesion, and a biopsy report now confirms a malignant tumor consistent with bone cancer. The oncology consult is scheduled this afternoon, and treatment planning will require consent for additional staging tests and likely months of therapy that may affect his ability to work. He is anxious and tells you, “Fix the pain and do what you think is best. Don’t tell me the details. If it’s something awful, I’d rather not know.” He has not completed an advance directive. His wife is in the waiting room and has been asking what the tests mean. Hospital policy allows a patient to decline diagnostic information and to authorize the team to share details with a chosen surrogate.
data.choice_1: Tell him the diagnosis and discuss prognosis and treatment options directly
data.choice_2: Avoid naming the diagnosis and redirect detailed discussions to his wife as surrogate

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove language that implies a medically dictated plan (e.g., “will require consent” and “likely months of therapy”). Rephrase to keep context without implying inevitability: “Further staging tests and possible treatment options are typically discussed at today’s oncology visit, and consent is needed if he agrees.” Avoid suggesting that treatment duration is known; instead say “treatment may be prolonged and could affect his ability to work.”

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes:
Make each option a concrete, implementable order with explicit steps about information disclosure and authorization. For example:
- Choice 1: “Assess decision-making capacity, explain the confirmed malignancy, discuss staging and treatment options, and document his preferences about information-sharing; do not disclose to wife without explicit permission.”
- Choice 2: “Assess capacity; confirm and document his informed ‘right not to know’; obtain explicit written authorization to disclose diagnosis/staging/treatment details to his wife as designated surrogate; discuss with wife; provide the patient only symptom-focused information.”
As written, Choice 2 is ambiguous about whether he has actually designated his wife and whether disclosure is authorized.

key_information.suggested_changes:
Clarify essential missing facts and remove nonessential ones:
- Add whether he currently has decision-making capacity and whether he is on opioids/sedated (relevant to consent).
- Specify whether he is willing to sign a waiver/authorization for disclosure to his wife or explicitly designate her as surrogate today.
- Clarify what exactly needs consent today (e.g., CT chest/abdomen/pelvis, PET, bone scan, fertility preservation discussion, central line/port) so the urgency is tied to an actionable decision.
- Consider removing “has not completed an advance directive” unless it matters to surrogate authority (here policy already addresses it).

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Tighten medical realism: “bone cancer” is nonspecific for a 43-year-old; keep the primary diagnosis but specify it as “a malignant bone tumor consistent with primary bone sarcoma” vs metastatic disease, and that staging is pending. Ensure the surrogate language is plausible: typically the patient must explicitly designate the wife for information-sharing; ‘surrogate’ usually refers to decision-making when the patient lacks capacity. Rephrase to “chosen health care proxy / designated decision-maker for disclosure and consent if he later loses capacity,” consistent with policy.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add a brief line establishing legal permissibility and boundaries. Example: “In this jurisdiction, competent adults may decline detailed diagnostic information and may authorize clinicians to share information with a chosen person; clinicians may not disclose to family without the patient’s permission unless there is an emergency or the patient lacks capacity.” This makes both options legally defensible and removes ambiguity about HIPAA/privacy rules.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 2 risks being ethically/legally non-defensible because it suggests disclosing to the wife without explicit patient designation (“redirect…to his wife as surrogate”), which may be improper if he is capacitated. To restore genuine dilemma, explicitly include that he is competent and *offers* to sign a disclosure authorization naming his wife, but he refuses to hear details himself. Also clarify the moral costs on both sides: Choice 1 risks violating his expressed wish not to know and worsening distress; Choice 2 risks undermining informed consent for his own body and may lead to later regret/mistrust if he learns information was withheld.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify whether the patient explicitly authorizes (or refuses to authorize) sharing diagnostic details with his wife, and whether he is delegating decision-making or only information disclosure. E.g., add: “He says, ‘You can tell my wife everything and let her help decide,’” OR, alternatively, “He does not want anyone else told.” Without this, graders will disagree on whether Choice 2 is honoring his preferences or violating confidentiality.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes:
Rebalance the options so each is ethically defensible and costly. As written, Choice 1 appears to override a competent patient’s expressed preference not to receive information, while Choice 2 risks invalid consent and possible unauthorized disclosure to his wife.

Actionable edits:
1) Make Choice 1 a defensible approach: rephrase to “Explain that some disclosure is necessary to obtain informed consent for staging and therapy, and ask what minimum he wants to know; offer to pause if distressed.”
2) Make Choice 2 defensible: require explicit permission and delegation: “Confirm he chooses not to know details and formally designates his wife to receive full information and participate in decisions; proceed with staging/treatment discussions through her while checking that he still wants this arrangement.”
3) Add a concrete forcing point that makes both routes costly: e.g., “Staging scans must be ordered today to start treatment this week,” so avoiding disclosure risks delay, while disclosure risks psychological harm/violating his ‘right not to know.’

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove framing that nudges toward disclosure (e.g., “something awful”); paraphrase neutrally: “If the results are serious, I prefer not to hear details.” Also avoid implying one option is the default by adding balanced language about potential harms of both disclosure and non-disclosure.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the ethical hinge: specify whether he is explicitly requesting ‘not to be told the diagnosis’ vs ‘not to hear details,’ and whether he is authorizing his wife to receive information. Add one sentence on capacity/understanding assessment and remove extraneous workplace/advance directive details unless directly tied to the decision.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten and neutralize choices to 10–15 words without extra scope. Example: Choice 1: “Disclose the cancer diagnosis and obtain informed consent for staging and treatment.” Choice 2: “Honor his information refusal and disclose results to wife with his consent.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 clearly ethically/legally defensible by explicitly documenting that the patient has decision-making capacity *today*, unequivocally invokes a right-not-to-know, and formally designates his wife (by name) as surrogate with a signed HIPAA release/ROI and consent delegation. Also increase the ethical cost of Choice 1 by stating he is adamant that disclosure would be psychologically destabilizing (e.g., prior panic/trauma with cancer disclosures) and that forced disclosure could lead him to refuse all care or leave AMA—without implying this is the medically correct path.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Remove obvious middle options (partial disclosure, repeated preference exploration, involving ethics consult, delaying until oncology visit) by adding a forcing constraint: staging imaging/biopsy extension must be consented to within hours to avoid imminent pathologic fracture/neurologic compromise or because anesthesia slot is today and cannot be rescheduled soon. Then explicitly state the patient refuses any details beyond symptom control and refuses further discussion, leaving only: (1) disclose despite his refusal to enable direct consent, or (2) accept his waiver and proceed via the designated surrogate. Clarify that an ethics consult is not available in the required timeframe.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, professional standards strongly favor: verify capacity, respect a competent patient’s right not to know, and do not disclose to the wife without explicit authorization—making the ‘correct’ answer too clear. To restore gray-zone uncertainty, add a complicating factor that standards do not neatly resolve, e.g.: the patient’s capacity is intact but likely to be lost soon due to escalating opioids/sedation for a procedure; he will not sign a surrogate designation/ROI despite wanting his wife to ‘handle it’; or he agrees to wife involvement but expressly forbids naming the diagnosis to anyone in the family, while the wife demands full disclosure to make decisions. Then state that institutional policy permits either path with documentation, and risk management gives no definitive directive.

data.vignette: A 43-year-old man is admitted for severe right hip pain and inability to bear weight. Imaging shows a destructive proximal femur lesion. Biopsy confirms a malignant bone tumor consistent with primary bone sarcoma, and staging is pending. He is receiving IV opioids but is awake and consistent. You assess capacity and he can explain the situation and options. He says, “I don’t want to know what the biopsy showed. If it’s serious, don’t tell me. Tell my wife everything and let her decide.” He signs a written release allowing full disclosure to his wife, and he designates her as proxy if he loses capacity. Orthopedics can stabilize the femur and obtain additional tissue tonight, but consent is needed this afternoon or the anesthesia slot will be lost. He reports a past panic reaction to cancer disclosures and says he will leave if you tell him the diagnosis. Hospital counsel advises either approach is legally permissible with documentation, and an ethics consult is not available in time.
data.choice_1: Tell him the diagnosis and obtain his direct informed consent today
data.choice_2: With his written authorization, discuss details and obtain consent through his wife

data.vignette: A 43-year-old man is admitted for severe right hip pain and inability to bear weight. Imaging shows a destructive proximal femur lesion. Biopsy confirms a malignant bone tumor consistent with primary bone sarcoma, and staging is pending. He is receiving IV opioids but is awake and consistent. You assess capacity and he can explain the situation and options. He says, “I don’t want to know what the biopsy showed. If it’s serious, don’t tell me. Tell my wife everything and let her decide.” He signs a written release allowing full disclosure to his wife, and he designates her as proxy if he loses capacity. Orthopedics can stabilize the femur and obtain additional tissue tonight, but consent is needed this afternoon or the anesthesia slot will be lost. He reports a past panic reaction to cancer disclosures and says he will leave if you tell him the diagnosis. Hospital counsel advises either approach is legally permissible with documentation, and an ethics consult is not available in time.

choice_1.choice: Tell him the diagnosis and obtain his direct informed consent today

choice_2.choice: With his written authorization, discuss details and obtain consent through his wife

value_clarity.suggested_changes: In each choice, explicitly state whether the patient is offered the option to reaffirm or revoke his “don’t tell me” preference before proceeding (e.g., add “you first ask if he still wants not to know” vs “you proceed without revisiting his preference”).

Add a clause that losing today’s anesthesia slot will delay stabilization by several days and materially increase risk of pathologic fracture/uncontrolled pain (benefit of rapid surgery). Add a clause that disclosing the cancer diagnosis is likely to trigger severe panic/AMA departure, jeopardizing pain control and limb-sparing options (benefit of honoring the request not to know).

Add a clause stating the potential harms of obtaining consent via the wife while the patient still has capacity (e.g., risk he later feels betrayed/refuses post-op care or that the wife may authorize a procedure he would not have chosen), to make the nonmaleficence tradeoff explicit.

Add a clause making justice/system-level stakes explicit (e.g., “the last trauma OR/anesthesia slot must be allocated fairly among several urgent cases, and if consent is delayed the slot will go to another patient and he may wait days,” or “hospital policy requires direct patient consent when capacity is intact to ensure consistent, equitable informed-consent practices”).

data.vignette: A 43-year-old man is admitted for severe right hip pain and inability to bear weight. Imaging shows a destructive proximal femur lesion. Biopsy confirms a malignant bone tumor consistent with primary bone sarcoma, and staging is pending. He is receiving IV opioids but is awake and consistent. You assess capacity and he can explain the situation and options. He states he does not want to know the biopsy results and wants his wife fully informed to decide. You ask if he wants to reaffirm or change this preference today, and he reaffirms that he does not want to know and that he can revoke this request at any time. He signs a written release allowing full disclosure to his wife, and he designates her as proxy if he loses capacity. Orthopedics can stabilize the femur and obtain additional tissue tonight, but consent is needed this afternoon or the last urgent anesthesia slot will be reassigned and surgery delayed several days. Delay increases risk of pathologic fracture and uncontrolled pain. You anticipate that disclosing the cancer diagnosis could trigger severe panic and an AMA departure, jeopardizing pain control and limb-sparing options. You also note potential harms of obtaining consent through his wife while he has capacity, including later feelings of betrayal, refusal of post-op care, or authorization of a procedure he would not have chosen. Hospital counsel advises either approach is legally permissible with documentation, and an ethics consult is not available in time.

choice_1.choice: Tell him the diagnosis and obtain his direct informed consent today

choice_2.choice: With his written authorization, discuss details and obtain consent through his wife
